text: Which are SUPERIMPOSED OVER a SCENE of almost unnatural beauty. A thickly wooded forest which practically shut ou the sunlight. All is not serene however. SHOTS RING Out - and we are privy to a running battle between a German pat and a band of Russian soldiers. It is a desperate fight - and several bodies fall. we see the faces of several men whose identity we will learn later. The shooting is still going on when the CREDITS come to an END. Then --

The CAMERA is MOVING SLOWLY up the hill. The verdancy of the hill, the intermittent clusters of daisies and dandel are evidence of the season -- late Spring. Now the crest the hill is in sight; above it a patch of blue sky is visible. The mood is pastoral, peaceful. The CAMERA reaches the crest -- and suddenly a pair of hi polished boots almost fills the SCREEN. The CAMERA comes to an abrupt HALT. Then SLOWLY, the CAMERA PANS UP from t boots to take in a carefully tailored German officer's un and then the face of the German officer -- CAPTAIN STRANS It is a longish face with a high forehead and light blue eyes. It is a face that gives an impression of extreme forcefulness, an impression underlined by the thin - lipp mouth and angular chin. His hair is white at the temples, emphasizing by contrast the healthy tan of his face. At the moment, Captain Stransky is gazing through a stere telescope. His expression is grim. Behind the Captain stands LIEUTENANT MEYER, a youngish, good-natured face.  However, it is apparent from his expression that he has no great liking for his Captain. His lips are tight as the Captain moves the knobs of the telescope with long th fingers. Captain Stransky straightens up, locks back at Lieutenant Meyer, whose expression quickly changes to one of impassivity. Stransky, whose demeanor is angry, says nothing, but turns to peer again through the telescope.

head_text.subj: VIEW THROUGH TELESCOPE WHAT CAPTAIN STRANSKY SEES

text: A patch of woods, about a square mile in area.
Stransky straightens up.
(angrily) Incredible -- sheer stupidity. Those woods should have been cut down or destroyed by fire.
Excuse me, sir, but we retreated too hastily for any such luxury.

I disagree. It was an irreparable oversight, and I shall send a report to that effect to Regiment. (looks at the woods, reaches for cigarette case ) Do you think the Russians are already in those woods? (offers Meyer a cigarette)
Thank you. We'II know soon enough. Corporal Steiner is on a recconnai sance patrol.  Stransky drops his cigarette butt, steps on it.
Reconnaissance patrols have a way of not returning.
Steiner will be back.

(angrily) I did not ask your opinion Herr Meyer. Meyer says nothing. We can see that he regrets his impu dence. With a mixture of anxiety and curiosity, he waits to see what will happen next. The ANGLE WIDENS to TAKE IN a PRIVATE who walks up to the Captain, salutes.

Captain Stransky? Lieutenant Colonel Brandt Would like to see you at headquarters. Stransky nods, gazes sharply at Meyer, walks off, the CAMERA TRUCKING with him. All about him are SCENES of great activity. MEN are digging bunkers and preparing positions. SHOUTS fill the air. As Stransky passes, he is greeted by salutes which he acknowledges with the briefest of nods.
An armed GUARD is on duty. He salutes smartly as .Captain Stransky comes INTO SCENE, returns the salute without looking at the Guard, ENTERS the bunker.

are examining a map that hangs on the wall. The older of the two is LIEUTENANT COLONEL BRANDT. About fiftytwo,  a gaunt gray face. The younger officer is a CAPTAIN. In his middle thirties, a tired expression, but his features are intelligent. At the moment, he is Shaking his head.
If our main line of resistance is at Novorssysk, What are We doing do@@nhere?
(shrugging) We're playing fire department.
Several hundred miles from the heart of the fire? Does that make sense? The door opens and a CORPORAL announces:
Captain Stransky.  Stransky APPEARS on the threshold.
Come in, Captain. You know my adjutant, of course.
Of course. How are you, Captain Kiesel?
Awful. Terrible. How are you? Brandt laughs, Places a bottle of wine on the table.
This might cheer you up, Kiesel. Stransky inspects the label.
My respects, Colonel Brandt. Producing a 1937 Moselle in the  southernmost corner of Russia.
(fills glasses) A bottle of Moselle is no more absurd in this region than We ourselves. Your health, gentlemen.
I am not going to drink to my health. My health is terrible and doesn't deserve to be drunk to. (holds up his glass) To the end of the damn war.
Incidentally, Colonel, why does our presence in the bridgehead strike you as so absurd?  Brandt looks at Kiesel, then turns to Stransky.
(ignoring the question) Captain, Why did you ask to be trans ferred from France?

(laughs) Exactly what my commanding officer in France asked me. I can't stop you, he Said, Since I'm convinced that without you the eastern front would collapse in a matter of days. Go ahead, you heroic fathead.
(quickly)  I withdraw my toast to the end of the war. To heroic fatheads everywhere. Stransky doesn't know quite how to take this, but decides on a faint, icy smile.
Captain Stransky, is there any news on Steiner?
No, sir, not yet. Brandt shakes his head.
Incidentally, What sort is he, Steiner? Kiesel looks at Stransky closely.
A problem....no respect, but a first rate soldier so one looks the Other Way. Pause.

(a short laugh) Of course, I've only been on this front a few days, matter of hours actually, but I see -- rather I sense -- a sort of -- well, it's not exactly insubordination -- Well, let's call it -- a lack of respect.
If I hope into a cab which gets into an accident because the brakes fail, I blame the driver, not the  company he works for. I'll say that he should have refused to drive a cab with defective brakes.
I'm not sure I know What you mean by that.
(looks at him a moment, then easily) I don't intend to discuss polities.
(angry) You talk avout lack of respect -- low morale..... it goes hand in hand with impending defeat.
Defeat? I refuse to admit that possibility.
(dryly) We'll, said, Captain.
I don't believe that the German soldier --

The German soldier! (laughs mirthlessly) In the early years they saw the retreating backs of the Russians too often to be frightened by his face now. The replacements, on the other hand, think every Russian  is an infallible fighting machine. I feel damn sorry for our poor land sers.
(frigidly) In the present state of our nation, such talk borders on treason. I am a soldier and as such it is my duty to subordinate my own ideas to the interests of my country.
(Smiles easily as he lifts glass) We are still doing our duty, Captain Stransky. Stransky, his face white, glares at Kiesel.  The PHONE has been RINGING. Brandt picks it up with a Snap.
Yes? -- What? -- Good, Meyer. Wonderful. What sort of shape are they in? -- I see. (hangs up) Lieutenant Meyer. Steiner is back.
Of course.
Naturally, I'd like to talk to him. I intend to promote him to Senior Sergeant on the spot.
(wryly)  Most generous of you.
(saluting) If you'll excuse me. Brandt nods. Stransky LEAVES. There is a moment's silence
Well, what do you think of our Captain?
(a moment's thought) Must have the most expensive tailor in Berlin.
And, of course, he won't rest until he gets the Iron Cross.
(toasts) Gets...... not earns? Brandt, who has lifted the wine bottle, finds it empty.
Oh, to hell with Stransky and the Iron Cross. And you, too, Kiesel. They smile at each other grimply.
Pacing back and forth in a trench, outside of a bunker door. Occasionally he steals a glance at a group of men who are slumped in various indolent positions on the floo of the trench.

The CAMERA PANS SLOWLY from face to face. There are nine men in the group (all will be identified later indi visually). At the moment, all look exhausted, dirty and somewhat disgusted. The men, with the exception of two, PASTERNACK and ANSELM, are in the same age range (about 25 to 30). Pasternack and Anselm are younger. SCHNUR BART is distinguished by a heavy beard. KRUGER by a tough weather beaten visage. DORN has the look of an intellectual. STEINER'S extreme gauntness is what catches the eyes. His face is expressionless. The others, MAAG, HOLLERBACH and KERN are nondescript, runofthemill faces. Meyer walks past the men in silence. They do not pay too much attention to him. Several are smoking cigarettes. Meyer looks toward the bunker. The CAMERA, following his gaze, MOVES TOWARD the bunker.
is seated at the table. He is a very young, very handsome officer. An orderly. KEPPLER, is busy at a hot plate with a coffee pot. He, too, is very young. After a moment --
Is it very hot? Captain Stransky won't stand for anything but hot coffee.
It is practically scalding, sir.
Good.
Is there anything else you wish, sir?
Not at the moment. As Keppler starts out:
Just a minute. You can keep me company for awhile. I really hardly know you. Sit down some where. Keppler looks around uncertainly. Triebig is sitting in t one and only chair.
Sit on the bed. Are you always so timid?

(with a shaky Smile) No. He perches on the extreme edge of the narrow bed. Triebig  studies him. Keppler's habitual expression is one of helplessness, accentuated by a mouth he keeps permanently slightly open.
Where do you come from?
Frankfurt, sir.
Is that so? I know Frankfurt quite well. (sits on the cot beside Keppler) If you get along with me, you'll have a good life here. You may go now. Come to my bunker tonight and arrange my gear.
(jumping enthusiastically to his feet) Yes, sir. When shall I come, sir?
Don't come too early. Around ten. We'll have a chance to talk. Do your best and I'm sure I shall be satisfied with you. Keppler salutes and GOES.
as Triebig COMES OUT. The men are watching Keppler as he WALKS OFF.
Not a very robust type, would you say?

(the youngest of the group) Well, Schnurrbart, you're so excessively masculine, it evens things up. The CAMERA PANS to Triebig. He seems to sense what the me are thinking. A bit disconcerted, he turns to Meyer.
(sardonically) Do you think we can get them to Stand at attention when the Captain gets here?
(grins)  I don't know, Lieutenant. I'll put it up to them, man to man. There is some half hearted laughter from the men. Steiner is noticeably quiet.
I'm not getting up till they want my Signature On the Peace Treaty. But he gees someone approaching, and slowly he starts to his feet.
approaching the trench. In the b.g. the men CAN BE SEEN reluctantly getting to their feet. Triebig snaps to atten as Stransky comes in.
(a Smart salute) Captain. Stransky, barely nodding to Triebig, looks over the men, discernible expression on his face. Finally --
Which one is Corporal Steiner? Steiner takes a step forward, slackly comes to attention. Stransky studies him -- disappointed.
You are Corporal Steiner?
(almost nonchalantly) Yes, sir. (pause) I am Corporal Steiner.
I had formed a -- somewhat different picture of you.

(unconcern in his face) I'm sorry if I disappoint the Captain. In the b.g. several of the men permit themselves slight smiles, which fade immediately at a glance from Triebig. Stransky looks at Steiner again.

(loudly) You are promoted to Senior Sergeant, promotion to be effective at once. He watches Steiner's face. It is as if he had spoken to a tree. There is no surprise in Steiner's face; only a slight flexing of his arms indicates that he has heard at all.
You heard me, Corporal -- Sergeant Steiner.
Yes, sir.
Your promotion doesn't seem to have made much impression upon you.
No, sir. There is an involuntary giggle from young Anselm. Stransk glares and there is silence.
(to Lieutenants Meyer and Triebig) Come in -- you, too, Sergeant. He starts down the steps to his bunker, Meyer, Triebig  and Steiner following.
is seated behind a table. Steiner, Meyer and Triebig, slightly to the side of him, stand facing Stransky, who has taken out an elaborate cigarette case. He extends it to Meyer who takes a cigarette.
Thank you, Captain. Stransky offers a cigarette to Steiner.
No, thank you, Sir.
(lighting his cigarette) After what you've been through, you don't feel the need of a cigarette?
No at this particular moment -- sir.
I'm ready for your report. He reaches into pocket, lays sheaf of crushed papers on t table. Stransky looks at him in amazement.
I'd like to hear the gist of your report.
Lots of Russians. Lots of guns. (grimly) We should be hearing from them very soon.
What about your platoon -- any casualties?
Two killed. One missing.
Two killed. How?
(dryly) Bullets.
(flushing angrily) I deduced that. That missing man -- did you look for him, Steiner?
(shrugs impatiently) We had no time to lose. It would  have been irresponsible to risk the safety of the entire platoon for the sake of one man.
There ought not to be a missing man in Such a case.
(no expression) Sorry, sir. I'll try to do better next time.
(grimly; after a moment) I have the feeling, Sergeant, that you somewhat overestimate your importance.
(eyes darken; but no change in voice) At the moment, I am free of any such illusions. The two men look at each other; then Stransky's eyes fall on the tommy gun Steiner holds in his hand.
That's not a German gun.
No, sir It's all in the report. We surprised a Russian platoon -- and when they ran, they left their guns.
Oh, captured material. Good.  Where is your gun?
We couldn't carry both, so we left ours.
What! You left your guns for the Russians!
(quietly) Yes, sir. Our guns for the Russians.
That I cannot understand. You must be aware that the quality of our arms is far superior to that of the Russians and -- He stops as Steiner shakes his head. Stransky raises his  eyebrows.
I beg your pardon?
...the Russian guns are better!
(sharply) That is stupid, loose talk. You have every reason to be grateful for the fine equipment the Father land puts into your hands at the cost of countless sacrifices.
(cannot suppress a mirthless grin) I never asked then to put the stuff  in my hands, Meyer looks toward heaven. Stransky takes a deep breath.
(hastily) sir, Sergeant Steiner is greatly in need of sleep. I'm positive that When he -- Stransky cuts him short by turning his back in a gesture dismissal. Meyer motions for Steiner to follow him.
jump to their feet as they see Steiner and Meyer.
Be careful he's taken strong dislike to you.
(wryly) Too bad. I'm crazy about him.
He can be trouble...
(laconically) I've survived many a battalion commander. I'll survive Stransky, too.
at his desk, coffee cup in hand, sipping.
Dammit. This coffee is cold.

Sorry, sir. It was heated not too long ago  There is a LOUD EXPLOSION as a shell lands nearby. The near miss has shaken up the bunker. Lieutenant Triebi is righting a table that has overturned. Captain Stransky girm faced, is dusting off his uniform.
(placing some papers on the table; feeble smile) Too close for comfort, I should say, Captain.
How many more papers are there for me to sign?
Quite a few, I'm afraid.

(sitting down; crossly) Let me have the junk. As he glances through the papers and signs his name. Trie watches him with his soft eyes, the smile remaining fixed on his face. As Stransky finishes signing he looks up, sniffs the air, looks at Triebig rather strangely.
That isn't perfume I smell -- is it?
Oh, no, Captain -- (apologetically Just a bit of after shave lotion. It -- bucks me up.
I see. He fixes his gaze upon Triebig whose smile fades under the  scrutiny. Then, Stransky's manner changes suddenly. He gestures toward a chair, tries to inject a cordial note into his voice.
(offering him a cigarette) Where were you stationed before you joined the battalion?
(voice softening) In the south of France -- Bordeaux.
Ah! Then being transferred must have come hare, eh? (voice casual) Why were you transferred anyway?
(after a moment's Silence) I voluntarily applied for a transfer, sir.

(suspiciously) How interesting. There is mounting apprehension in Triebig's face as Stran regards him fixedly. Then again there is a sudden change Stransky's expression. Again it becomes friendly -- to Tr great relief.

We lived in real mansions right On the beach. Swimming at any hour, day or night. It was indescribable  -- the sea, the palms, the beaches, the people, everything -- Overwhelmed by his memories, he stops. Stransky is surpri to see him swallow with emotion.
(a knowing smile; winks) The women, you mean.
(raising his head@j I beg your pardon?
I said, the women. I mean -- in referring to the people -- you meant, of course, the women?
(shrugging) Not so much that. I am -- that is-- (suddenly confused I didn't have much time to think about women. Pause.
(casually) Do you like soldiering?
(emphatically) Certainly.
(nods patronizingly) I'm glad to hear that.
It's like living in an altogether different world. The Candle hag burned down. Stransky rises to light anoth

It is indeed a very different world. A world of danger and a world of men, a world without women. (laughs; puffs, gets thoughtful) men can get along without women. I tell you, man's truly natural destiny is not to breed children, but to be free, to rule and fight -- in other words, to lead a man's existence.... women are no more than a fancy,  a superfluous dessert. (blows a smoke ring; looks at Triebig) Or do you disagree? Triebig looks at Stransky in some confusion. What is Stra getting at. Then he gets a grip on himself. Intertwining his fingers, he regards his thumb thoughtfully.
I don't think I disagree, sir. (after some hesitation) I think that if I have to I Can live without women.
I'm pleased to hear that. He studies the burning tip of his cigarette; then looks u  quickly.
In other words, you prefer the company of a man to that of a woman?
(greatly troubled now) It depends on the situation.
Really? Stransky smiles. Triebig does not reply.

If it will help you, I will put your thoughts into words for you. (smilebroadens) You prefer the society of men to  that of women in any and all situations. The words hang in the silence of the bunker. Triebig re- treats into himself like a snail sealing itself up in its shell. He stares with mingled fear, assent and hope at Stransky's face which still registers nothing but friendl assent. Then, afraid silence might be interpreted as agreement, he murmurs...
I -- don't understand, sir --
(smiles confidentially) Let's drop the hide and seek. By God, Triebig, you don't have to put up a front with me of all people. What I said is true,  isn't it? Say yes, man, for heaven's sake.
(with the air of a man wanting to stop himself; in a bare whisper) Yes. Stransky springs to his feet, directly in front of him.

Speak up! You said yes. You said yes. didn't you? Don't you dare lie to my face. At the sight of Stransky's enraged face, only a few inche from his own, Triebig closes his eyes in horror. Stransky shakes him.
(feebly) Yes.
(releasing him; stepping back) Stand up! Trembling, Triebig obeys. Slowly, and down.

I can assure you of this! If I catch you trying any of that stuff, I'll have you hanged, remember that! Before all the men! Do you understand that? Do you hear me? Stransky looks him up  Triebig is unable to answer.
Now get the hell out of here and keep out of my sight for the next twenty-four hours. You turn my stomach. Triebig stands immobile.

Get out! For a second Triebig looks at Stransky's distorted face. Then he wheels around, stumbles across the threshold I en VANISHES. Stransky remains in the same spot for a moment, then he fishes for a cigarette, smiles. He is satisfied with the picture of the complete military, masculine imag he has presented.
Steiner walking watching men digging in, goes into Brandt's bunker after looking up at the sky for a long mo
The door opens and Steiner COMES IN. The scowl leaves Brandt's face. He strides forward to meet Steiner; presses his hand vigorously.
So here are you -- unpunctual and unsoldierly as ever. He laughs and propels Steiner toward a chair.

(laughs) I read your report. It's enormously valuable. I intend to transmit it personally to the General -- Ah,  one thing. Captain Stransky has sent in an official complaint about the guns. What have you to say to that?
(stolidly) What can I Say? I threw away German guns to make room for Russian guns.
Why?
The Russian guns are better. I know it. You know it. The men know it. Captain Stransky seems somewhat in the dark. Brandt looks at him.
You're a fresh bastard, aren't you?
Yes, sir. Brandt looks at Steiner and crumples Stransky's report. H offers Steiner a cigarette.
Last month I offered to pull you out of the line and give you a staff post?
Yes, sir --- and I remember refusing.
....something about your feeling of solidarity with your men. Well --  I renew the offer. I want you on my staff. No answer from Steiner.
All right -- what's the reason for refusing this time?
(after a moment) I don't want to be dependent on anyone -- not even a regimental commander.
As usual, I find it hard to under- stand you.
(dryly)  I'm sorry to hear that. A good sgt. should be completely under- stood by his superior officer.
Steiner! Are you laughing at me? (getting up) Steiner stands up and looks expectantly at Brandt, whose mouth twitches.
(voice shaking) Get out! Steiner half salutes and leaves.
in machine gun emplacement. Darkness has fallen. Maag is looking out into the night. Suddenly, a Russian sub-  machine gun OPENS UP. head in the dirt. Maag, frightened, tries to bury his

walking in the darkness. At the BURST of BULLETS, he has dropped to one knee. Now, there is silence again, and Steiner peers cautiously into the darkness. There is ANOTHER BURST of FIRE ground. Then there is quickly and bounds to -- bumping into Maag, BURST of BULLETS.
(shouting to be heard) Where are you going?
and Steiner stretches out flat on the silence again. Steiner gets up the nearest machine gun emplacement who is trying to get out. Another  (stammering) To -- get reinforcements.

(angrily) Leaving your post for that? He pushes Maag back into the hole. They huddle together t the Russian machine guns are quiet. Then Steiner peers through the loophole. A few shells WHINE through the air, EXPLODE nearby.

(gasping) They must be right in front of us. In the Shell holes down there. Behind them there is the SOUND of RUNNING FEET and Schnur dives into the emplacement. Behind him come Kruger and  Hollerbach, and Lieutenant Meyer.
What's happening?
The big craters on the slope are full of Russians. Meyer stands frowning for a few seconds, then:
(to Steiner) Signal for a barrage. Kruger -- get the rest of the company. I'll inform the Commander. He hurries OUT. Steiner picks up the flare gun. Back bent, he LEAVES the emplacement.
as he reaches a position in the trench. He inserts the cartridges in the flare gun. He sends up a FLARE.

ILLUMINED by the FLARE. The dark shapes of the Russians a visible in the craters. Then there is darkness -- then on again the landscape is ILLUMINED. The dark shapes can be seen burrowing into the ground.

He is looking at his watch with bated breath. Then he smi grimly as a hollow roaring SOUNDS above his head. It swel rapidly to a mighty moan and a moment later comes the hea detonation. Steiner turns as he HEARS hasty FOOTSTEPS. He sees Meyer running past him toward the MG emplacement. Steiner follows.
as Steiner slides IN, followed by Meyer. The men of the  platoon are already assembled.

Commander's order. The Second Platoon is to undertake a counter- attack at once. You are to occupy the craters and take as many prisoners as possible. Sergeant Steiner, you will command. How do you think to proceed?

(considersbriefly We'll attack from three sides. Kruger from the west, Schnurrbart from the east and I from the south. When the firing starts We'll need artillery support -- to keep the Russians pinned  down in the woods. I guess that's all.
(nodding) Good in theory; let's hope it works out in practice.
(smiles grimly) It's too simple; it'll never work. All right -- First Platoon, down the trench till I step you. With bent backs, Anselm and Pasternack in the lead, the m start down the trench.
as with bent backs and faces taut with tension they proce down the trench. The CLATTER of weapons persists. The men stop, look at each other -- some with frightened
(With a nervous laugh) Sergeant -- could I go make a telephone call? A titter, totally Without mirth, runs through the men.
(to Kruger) You and your boys stay here. Steiner raises his arm. The rest of the men follow him.
as Steiner and the men come INTO VIEW. Steiner raises his hand in a signal to halt. Then he peers over the trench, lifts himself over, gives the signal for the men to follo
We SEE the shadowy figures of Steiner and the men descen the slope. When they reach the level field Steiner again gives the signal to halt.
(to Schnurrbart) You wait here. Attack in exactly five minutes -- Schnurrbart looks at his watch.
As soon as the first shots are fired, we'll come in. Clear?
(grunting) All Clear. He shakes hands with Steiner, who walks into the darkness followed by Kern, Anselm and Pasternack.
trudging toward a clump of woods. Suddenly, Steiner drops to the ground.
The other men have wordlessly followed his example. Ansel crawling on his belly, comes INTO THE SCENE.
(whispering) What's wrong? Steiner points his head leftward. Anselm follows his gaze
moving cautiously through the darkness. They are no more than twenty yards away.
Russkis! At least a hundred of  them! Steiner is hesitant.
How many men has Schnurrbart got -- a dozen? They'll run right over them.
Why don't we fire on them now?
That may louse up the whole counter- attack. (bites his lips as he thinks hard) Schnurrbart probably won't even see them coming -- He reaches into his belt for flares.
A couple of flares -- and Schnurrbart can see he's getting visitors -- Then if we start shooting up their rear -- (shrugs) Maybe, the confusion -- He sends up two flares in quick succession.
is taken by surprise. SHOTS RING OUT, several fall.

All right -- after them. Stick close together and don't save on hand grenades. (ironically)  Remember, the eyes of the entire German nation are upon you. He runs in the direction of the Russians, the men followi

The air is crackling with the SOUND of GUNFIRE and heavy EXPLOSIONS. Captain Stransky comes running OUT of the bunker, followed by Lieutenant Triebig. A Private comes running INTO the SCENE from the opposite direction.
Word from Corporal Schnurrbart, sir. The Russians have broken into the trenches. Triebig looks alarmed.
(to Triebig) Take up positions in front of the  bunker with all the men attached to staff. I'll phone the combat train. He turns and runs hack INTO the bunker.
manning a machine gun. They are lying on the slope FIRING toward the trenches.
We've mowing them down.
Who? Ours or theirs?
There is the SOUND of faraway BURSTS of machine gun fire. Hollerbach and Kern are helping Anselm who is limping badly. Behind them are Dorn and Kruger. All look weary and begrimed.
as they come IN. (to Anselm) You're a damn fool not to go to the Field Hospital --
(sinking to the floor) I'll wait until the holiday rush is over. Otherwise, they're just as likely to amputate as not.
Does anybody still have any idea what the hell went on?
(who seems dazed)  --- confusion --- confusion --
I couldn't see anything. When something moved I fired at it. Probably got as many Germans as Russians.
Shut up!
Please -- a little respect for a wounded man. Steiner comes IN. He has a bandage on top of his head.
Kruger, what happened to you at the signal?
I was Clearing Out the craters -- then I heard the firing from your direction --
I was wondering if you were waiting for a formal invitation.
You know what you can do with your fuckin' sarcasm. I saved your ass.
Oh, did you? Well, you know what You can do with my --
as Stransky and Triebig come IN. The men start to come to attention.
(curtly) At ease. (to Steiner) That was a bad business. You know half of 2nd Company was put out of action?
Yes, Sir. Our platoon was hit, too.
Why didn't the plan go according to schedule?
We didn't think that --

He is now close enough to the beach to stand. He takes an  uncertain step or two to stand, then he falls, his face down in the water. He makes no effort to rise -- allowing himself to slide deeper and deeper into the water. Sudden Gertrud's hands come INTO THE SCENE, grip Steiner's feet, pull him back.

Struggling for breath, he lies on the ground. Steiner turns over on his back and looks at her. There is rage and shame on his face. The blood starts streaming do his face again. He tries to sit up. She tries to support him and he knocks her arm back.

If you don't leave me alone I'll smash -- He stands up, takes a few steps to meet the incoming surf bends, scoops up a handful of water, washes the blood fro  his face. Then he turns and sees that Gertrud has retreated a few f up the beach, and stands watching him. The wind is blowin her skirt close to her thighs. He looks at her a moment, then, CAMERA TRUCKING with him, makes his way to her side. Gertrud looks at him steadily. Suddenly he seizes her. She struggles, wordlessly. Steine forces her to the ground. With one swift movement he pull her blouse from off one shoulder.

She has stopped struggling. His face is close to hers. There is no resistance in her expression, but neither is there compliance. She looks steadily into his eyes as if there is a battle of wills. Roughly Steiner grabs her shoulders. Suddenly, he releases her, stands up. He watches her as she slowly sits up, rearranging her clothi  He stares at her without Speaking. Then --
(in a low voice) Why did you follow me? She doesn't answer. He shakes his head slightly.
Nurse Gertrud. keep your humanitarian paws off drunken men. It might be misunderstood.
(breathing heavily You'reinsane.
(laughs harshly) We are all insane.  (he makes a tiny, mocking bow) goodnight. He walks toward the blackness of the garden. Gertrud turn to watch him until He is no longer in sight.

has just reached his bedroom door He is about to go in, when he stops, hesitates. Then he walks slowly to the nex door, leans forward, listening. He glances up and down th hall, then Slowly depresses the latch.
A streak of LIGHT coming through a space afforded by the blowing curtains. As Steiner COMES IN, we SEE Inge's shap sitting up in bed.
Who's there?
(Closing the door behind him) Three guesses. Inge, her long nightgown trailing around her ankles, him in the darkness.
Leave my room at once.

Out of character, but very nicely said. Don't worry; I just wanted to ask you if you have any aspirin. approaches Inge comes two steps Closer, looks at him. She hesitates. As she turns toward the door, he grips her shoulders and holds her tightly.
Were you going to turn on the light?
Yes.
(feeling along her arms) You don't need any light, take my word for it. Pretending to struggle, she manipulates the nightgown off right shoulder, a maneuver not lost upon Steiner.
Let me go. I'll scream. I will scream.
Naturally, you'll scream.  She closes her arms tight around his shoulders. When she tries to kiss him he turns his face aside. He picks her up and as he carries her toward the bed:
framed in a window. CAMERA PULLS BACK to the interior of Inge's bedroom. Inge is lying in bed. Steiner is sitting on the edge of the bed, his back to Inge, looking out the window.
Funny -- you boasted about your view of the sunset. I prefer the sunrise. Inge laughs. She sits up, throws her arms around his ches
You know -- never once last night did you say my name.  (strokes his chest) Don't you like my name?
Why shouldn't I like it?
Up to this moment I've never met a girl named Inge. At least not in bed. Inge laughs. When Steiner makes a move to get up, she hol him tighter.
Where are you going? He pulls himself loose, walks to where his shoes lying, picks then up. Inge, blanket up under her chin, watches h He turns.
Goodnight.
(angrily) Aren't you at least going to kiss me? He stoops and casually kisses her shoulder.
Is that all?

Isn't it enough? Do you want to get paid? She starts up as though the pillow behind her had become hot iron. Then she throws herself face down on the bed, begins to sob wildly. Steiner stands for a moment, looking at her in embarrassment and some remorse.
(sadly)  Depend on me to say a few words to many. He walks slowly to the door, closes it behind him. 74. DELETED.
who has just COME IN and is talking to a MAN at the bar.
He sinks back into his seat, looks off at Gertrud. Then he rises and, CAMERA TRUCKING with him, winds his way across the floor to her. Her back is to him.
(quietly) Gertrud -- She turns, flushes as she sees him, but doesn't say a wor
I wish -- I were meeting you for  the first time now.
(looks at him) I suppose that's as close to an apology as you, Can ever get -- If you'll excuse me.... He makes a gesture to stop her, but she brushes past him. We hear Klaus' voice.
Rolf -- Steiner turns to face Klaus.
She's here --!
(Pre-occupied) Who?
You know -- Ilse -- the Iron Cross Tits --
Listen I don't want -- He has turned automatically to look toward the corner of the bar. At the sight of the GIRL in the nurse's white uniform, Steiner's speech stops; his eyes narrow.
She is looking toward Steiner, an expectant smile on her face. She is very buxom and very pretty in a coarse way.

Steiner's face is expressionless. CAMERA TRUCKING with him, he makes his way to the Waiting Ilse. En route he passes Gertrud who, struck by the grimness of Steiner's expression, keeps her eyes on him as he pushes toward Ils
Her smile freezes as Steiner STEPS INTO the SCENE.
(steadily) Good evening, Ilse. She can only stare at him.
I can't blame you, Ilse. After all, it's been -- how long --? More than a year anyway. Yes, thirteen months --
(in a very low voice) Rolf --

-- and the law of averages -- What right have I to be alive -- Did you count on that, Ilse? Suddenly, Ilse lets out a sob, covers her face with her then turns and runs toward the exit. Klaus, who has stood few paces behind, comes up to Steiner.
I must say -- it's a strange effect you have upon women. Steiner doesn't answer. Klaus shakes his head, goes after Ilse.

Whose eyes haven't left Steiner. She watches him now as h sits down at an unoccupied table. From his inside pocket he takes out a piece of paper. She sees him flag a passin WAITER. A brief conversation ensues between them, and the Waiter lends Steiner a pencil. As Steiner begins to write Gertrud moves slowly toward him.

As Gertrud's shadow falls across the table he looks up briefly, goes back to his writing. Without a word, Gertru slips into a chair across from Steiner. After a moment, h finishes writing, looks at Gertrud.
I imagine you want to know what it's all about?
No.
Be honest.
Yes, I do. Very much. Pause.

It's not too pretty a story -- and it  isn't very chivalrous of me to tell it. But, then, one of the first casualties of the war was chivalry -- (looks at the slip of paper) A year or so ago I was in a hospital. In four years of war I have been in four hospitals. (harshlaugh) Some day I must get around to rating them. Anyway -- Ilse -- Miss Bauman -- decided she would be more than a nurse to me. After three days and three nights I told her to be more than a nurse to somebody else. (looks at Gertrud's face) He is silent a moment, his face reflecting the humiliatio
She found a way to get even -- result -- Court martial -- degraded -- Six months in a Penal Battalion -- (pause. Holds up the paper) Now, I in tend to have Miss Bauman's signed confession --

Please -- don't be brutal to her -- He gets up. She looks at him in mute appeal. He shakes his head, Starts out, Gertrud looking after him. He gets up. She looks at him in mute appeal. He shakes his head, star out, Gertrud looking after him.

On a corner of the bench, Ilse is huddled, still sobbing In the b.g. a figure looms. Then a flashlight, in the hand of the figure is snapped on. Its beam ILLUMINATES Ilse, who doesn't move. The figure, holding the flashligh moves closer, and we SEE that it is Steiner. Now he stand beside Ilse, who does not look up.
Turn it out -- I can't see. Steiner snaps off the light. She looks up at him, her fac a study in fury.
You Stinking louse.
(laughs grimly) I that What I am?
(violently) Yes. And you always were a louse. You never knew how to treat a woman.
How right you are. And now, let me prove your point -- (takes Out the Slip Of paper) -- Sign this.
What is it?
Your confession.
Confession. What have I to confess?

Oh -- are we going to play games? All right, I'll read it to you -- (snaps on the flashlight, starts to read) On the night of May 12, 1943, I, Ilse Bauman, a nurse at the 2nd Base Hospital in Rostov, stole a wrist- watch from the room of Corporal Karl Wachtel, an amputee, and furthermore, hid the watch among the belongings of -- Sgt. Rolf Steiner. Suddenly, Ilse jumps to her feet, starts to run, knocking the flashlight from Steiner's hands. But Steiner catches her in two strides. She kicks him and pummels him with he fists. Steiner drags her down to the water, wades in kne deep and thrusts her head under.
holding Ilse's head under water. Then he pulls her up by the hair.

Will you sign now? She coughs and struggles for breath. He picks her up in h arms, carries her back to the bench, dumps her on it unce moniously. He picks up the pencil and paper and the flash light. He flashes the LIGHT on her face. Water is drippin from her hair down her forehead and onto her hands.

Maybe in bed you could cry your way out, but not here. He thrusts the pencil into her hand. He flashes the LIGHT  on the bench so that Ilse can see. With trembling hands, she signs the paper. Steiner switches off the flashlight.
(looking at paper) All right -- you may go now. She doesn't stir.
(repeats sharply) You may go now. Unsteadily, she gets to her feet, looks at him.
(tonelessly) You're going to report me. He nods grimly.
Oh, God. Oh, God, what am I going  to do? He shrugs. Slowly she walks away, her wet skirt clinging to her legs, head bowed, shoulders twitching.

watching Ilse go. There is no pity in his face. Then, he sits on the bench, examines the paper closely. He is deep in thought when there is the SOUND of SOFT FOOTSTEPS in t sand. Steiner looks up, Gertrud stands beside him.

(quietly) So you have what you want? Steiner nods his head slowly, looks at the paper again. T he gets up, walks to the water's edge. For a moment, he hesitates, then he tears the paper into tiny scraps, toss them into the water. Gertrud comes INTO the SCENE, stands  at Steiner's side. Together they watch the scraps being carried out on the waves, dancing and scattering until th vanish from sight. There is a moment's silence, broken by Gertrud.
Why?
(shrugs; then, slowly) I'm not interested anymore in clearing my name. Doesn't matter..... He starts away.
Rolf-- He stops, turns, looks at Gertrud.
as she looks steadily toward Steiner.
He walks to her. Without a word he takes her in his arms. They cling to each other.
Gertrud, her knees drawn up, sits facing the sea. Steiner sits at right angle to Gertrud, his head resting on her shoulder, as he reads a letter:

"-- Well, here I am, back in dear old Mother Russia, after six weeks in the hospital. Why did no one eyer tell me before about the pleasures of being wounded? That nice, clean hospital -- the food -- those nurses -- rather, that one  nurse in particular. But why am I telling you. Every hospital, I hear has that one particular specimen... " He turns his head to look at Gertrud. They smile at each other. Then he resumes reading.

Anyway -- "At the moment things are quiet here, so you can be sure the Russkis are preparing something big. I suppose you heard that Dorn got it. We had finally persuaded the professor to put in for Officers Training, and the very next day the Russkis lobbed over a few shells to let us know they're still in business --"  He stops reading. Gertrud looks at him.
Bad you heard of it?
No.
Were you fond of him?

The professor? I don't know -- not particularly, I guess. (reflects a moment) He was a good soldier. Did his job. (pause) I'm sorry he's gone. (back to letter)  "Well, to get on to more cheerful news. Our darling Captain Stransky is in some sort of trouble --" (looks up from letter) Him -- I can be more definite about. (resumes reading) "Seems in the Captain's report on the Russian action, the night we got it, he somewhat overplayed his hand. His report, I hear, pictures Stransky, accompanied by Triebig, appearing at the last moment among his fleeing men, stemming the panic, and leading the counterattack --" (pauses)  A damned lie! (back to letter) "From what I hear, Stransky sat out the engagement in his bunker. Colonel Brandt informed Stransky that he was entitled to the Iron Cross First Class for bis actions, but he also pointed out that two witnesses were required. Triebig, that sweet- smelling skunk, naturally signed, but the signature of the Company Commander was also needed. Since Lieutenant Meyer was killed and you were then in charge, it looks like you're elected. We can't wait until you get back and are asked  to sign. So, don't linger by the wayside. Hurry back and join the fun. Keep well and watch out that they don't pick you up and stick you in some other unit. Things are supposed to be pretty hot on the main front. All the best, your old friend, Schnurrbart." Steiner looks out at the sea. After a moment...
You don't want to go back do you?
(Pause) Not now.
(trying to sound  cheerful) In the morning you're going home for a month. I know it sounds crazy -- out maybe in a month it'll all be over.
It'll never be over. Not for me. He falls silent. The POUNDING of the SURF can be HEARD. Gertrud stretches her hand out to Steiner.
Rolf -- sit beside me. He takes her outstretched hand, sits beside her, rests his head on her breast. She puts her arm around him. He lies quietly for a moment, then lifts his face to kiss her.
No, darling -- later -- later -- later -- Her arms around him, she is rocking him almost like a child as we:
There are two fleets of army trucks lined up. On one side of the street the trucks face west; on the opposite side they face east. SOLDIERS are boarding both fleets of trucks.
He calls out to a soldier who is walking hesitantly to- ward the trucks facing west.
You there -- let me see your orders. The soldier hands his orders to Muller, who looks at then

Where do you think you are going? (with sadistic glee) These trucks are going home. You belong there -- (Pointing to east- bound trucks) You're going to the front! (pointing to west- bound trucks) Lucky ones there! (waves to east bound trucks) Unlucky ones there! (laughs again)
standing outside the rest home, near the parked trucks. H is looking up and down the street -- evidently waiting fo Someone. Muller, who CAN BE SEEN in the b.g. , calls out
Steiner--! Get into your truck. It's ready to move!
as Steiner walks slowly up to him.
What's wrong, Sergeant? For one of the lucky ones, you sure don't seem anxious to go. Steiner doesn't even look at Muller who evidently sees so at the west trucks.
Hey, you there -- let me see your Orders -- He runs off, almost colliding with Inge. She looks compla
Goodbye, Sergeant Steiner.
I'm touched. Up this early just to say goodbye to me. Or are you waiting to welcome the new batch coming in?
No. I just thought somebody should say goodbye to you. (smiles as Steiner looks at her) Gertrud is not coming, Sergeant. He stares at her. She takes ah envelope out of her pocket
This is for you.  As he snatches it out of her hand.....
That's all right. I've already read it.
You're a pig. (looks at the envelope, but doesn't open it)

I'll be happy to read it to you. She takes the envelope from him. neither objecting nor assenting. He just stands there, Inge's tone, as she reads, is not as triumphantly smug as might have been expected.

(reads)  "Dearest Rolf -- I can't face you this morning. How can you and I know what we feel for each other? We hate so quickly and easily, maybe we fall in love too quickly and easily, too. There are things I even needed to tell you about..... Steiner snatches the letter from Inge. crumples it in his hand. His face is his usual steel mask again. He stands still for a moment, then the SOUND of the truck MOTORS causes him to look up. The trucks bound for the front have started slowly off. Steiner looks at the crumpled letter in his hand, throws it away, runs for the trucks.
as Steiner runs past him. He stares in amazement as Steiner jumps onto the back of the last truck heading eas
(almost screaming) No! No! Steiner -- wrong truck! You're going home. That one's going to the front! Steiner -- Steiner -- ! But in the b.g. the truck has disappeared around the corn

head_text.subj: ROAD SKIRTING A ROW OF BUNKERS

text: A truck is seen coming to a stop. A lone figure jumps off back, waves to the driver. The truck drives on.

standing in the road, looking about him with some curiosi  Then, CAMERA TRUCKING with him, he starts to walk. He passes several SOLDIERS. We can tell by the cursory glanc they exchange that they are strangers to each other. Steiner enters the bunker.

rounding a corner near the bunker. He HEARS SHOUTS from t bunker and stops. Then he HEARS a half dozen voices CRYIN in unison, "Steiner! Steiner! Steiner!" Triebig's face sets. He stands a moment, immobile, then turns, hurries away in the opposite direction.
Kruger, Kern, Schnurrbart and Anselm are grouped around Steiner. A NEWCOMER stands off to the side a bit. Steiner is opening a beer bottle.
You're an idiot, Rolf. Why didn't  you go home when you could have?
(stony-faced) Heard it was safer here. (nodding) I was home for two weeks.

(angrily) I wish this kind of talk would stop. It's -- it's gross exaggeration -- and what's more, it has a terrible effect on the morale of the troops at the front! Everyone turns to look at the newcomer. coolly. Steiner regards him
What's your name?
(defiantly) Zoll.
Thank you, Herr Zoll for worrying about my morale. The men laugh.
Zoll is a Party member. He's con- vinced we're winning the war, and anybody who doesn't think so, he's quite willing to turn in to the Storm Troops.
(to Zoll) My name is Rolf Steiner -- and please memorize my correct serial number. I wouldn't want them to come for the wrong man. The PHONE RINGS. Zoll answers it.
(very snappy) Second Platoon. Zoll speaking.
God, isn't it wonderful hearing a real soldier speaking again.
(through the men's laughter) Yes, sir -- yes, sir --  (hangs up, turns to Steiner Captain Stransky wants to see you in his bunker.
When?
Right away.
Good. I missed my Captain Stransky.
The CAMERA PULLS BACK and we SEE that we are in what is evidently Stransky's bunker. Triebig is facing Stransky. It is now dark.
I'll soften him up, don't worry.  How long have we kept him waiting?
About half an hour.

All right. Send him in. Triebig, still looking worried, goes OUT. Stransky stands for a moment, moves another chair to the table, then sits opposite it. The door opens and Steiner comes IN. He look at Stransky, his face devoid of expression.
with Steiner in b.g. Stransky's demeanor is carefully matter-of-fact.
Welcome back, Sergeant. Please sit down. (impatiently, as  Steiner remains standing) You may sit down.
If you order me to.
Consider it an order. Reluctantly, Steiner sits down facing Stransky, who moves kerosene lamp so that he himself is sitting in darkness.
Are you quite recovered from your wound?
Quite.
Good. Now that you're back, I'm  willing to make a fresh start. I excuse your past behavior. There are several important matters I wish to discuss with you.
(his face shows that he knows what Stransky has in mind 1 there is a pause before he speaks) Certain things can be talked about only man to man, not superior to subordinate.

(an attempt at a smile) You would naturally think that.  But, you know, don't you, that in civilian life, too, a distinction is made between people and personalities? For a fleeting moment Steiner's expression darkens, but h quickly composes his features. His tone is ingenuous.
I don't. But I'm'sure you can explain that distinction to me.

(smoothly) I can. The difference is a matter of ethical and intellectual super- iority and is caused, whether you like it or not, by class difference. Those who are reared in dirt will never or rarely emerge from it  because they have never learned to see dirt as dirt. Isn't that self - evident?
(swiftly and quietly I disagree. Talent, sensitivity and character are not privileges of the upper class.
(voice less urbane) I see. May I ask which of the two categories you count yourself? It is an open challenge. Steiner sits up in his seat.
Is this conversation taking place between two equal human beings, or  between a superior and his sub- ordinate?
(haughtily) I see no reason to throw the weight of my rank into the balance.
(quietly) In that case, I am free not to answer your tactless question. There is e silence as fury mounts in Stransky's eyes, but he controls his voice.
You are forgetting yourself, Steiner.
(coldly)  If you feel insecure about standing on your grounds of equality, we can easily go back to our regular relationship.

(looks at his hands, speaks softly) Your impertinence can only come from stupidity -- and digging holes. (stands up brusquely and paces the room several times be- fore he comes to a stop in front of Steiner) I have met more than one person of  your type -- and I have always crushed them like vermin. I consider you nothing more than an insolent lout who cannot keep his hands off his comrades' property.
as he stands up slowly. He makes a visible effort to control himself.
(voice steady and quiet) You'll regret that.
Steiner wipes his sleeve with his right hand.
For that remark alone, back home I would have had dogs chase you over the fields until your feet were bleeding straps.
We're not back home.
You'll wish you were before long. (turns his back on Steiner, picks up the phone) Triebig? Come in here! He hangs up, turns, sees that Steiner is leaning easily against the wall.
Stand at attention!  Steiner takes a half step forward, lets his arms dangle. The door opens and Triebig COMES IN.
How far has my new bunker progressed?
About a foot and a half.
The bunker is to be ten feet deep. Sergeant Steiner will work on it tonight until that depth is reached.
(astonished) Tonight?
Tonight. I shall hold your respon- sible for having that bunker ready  by tomorrow morning.
Yes, sir. Steiner has listened with an impassive face. Now, without change of expression, he holds the door open for Triebig, then he turns to look at Stransky. without a word, he GOES OUT.
as they walk toward the spot (seen in b.g.) where the new bunker is being dug. They walk in silence a moment.
I want you to know I have nothing to do with this business.
That's lucky for you. (pause)  Where's your "friend"?
(looking straight ahead) He's dead.
Oh -- too bad. (sardonically) Well -- bear up. Fresh recruits are coming in every day. Triebig looks at him and his voice shakes with hatred.
I have only one wish, and the Commander shares it. We could court martial you or get rid of you some other way. But we want  to have the pleasure of seeing you -- croak.
(smiles) You'll have to take very good care of yourself if you want to outlive me. Triebig clenches his fists in helpless fury.
Thank you for the warning.
You're entirely welcome. By this time they have reached the pit where four men are digging.
(to the men)  Ail right -- you're relieved. You may return to your quarters. The men, seeing only Steiner with Triebig, don't quite comprehend.

(shouting) I said you may return to your quarters! The men hastily drop their shovels, clamber out of the pi and walk AWAY. They keep looking back at Triebig and Steiner, still not certain of what's going on. Triebig turns to Steiner.
If I were you, I'd make sure it was done by morning.
It won't be for lack of trying, sir. Triebig glowers at him, walks AWAY. Steiner jumps into the pit, starts to shovel. The CAMERA notes that Steiner is up to his kneecaps in the pit.

The CAMERA PANS UP from the boots to Steiner's face. Steiner is asleep in a chair, his feet stretched out. The scene is the outer room of Brandt's command post. After a moment, the inner door opens and Kiesel and Triebig COME OUT.
You'll wait here, Lieutenant. Triebig nods nervously, Kiesel looks at Steiner, shakes his head.
Steiner! Steiner opens his eyes, stumbles to his feet, straightens up. Kiesel holds the door open. Steiner looks at Triebig, then walks IN.
Brandt is sitting behind a huge, clumsy desk piles with all sorts of useless objects. He holds a lighted cigarett between his fingers. Steiner and Kiesel COME IN.
So there you are. Next time you're wounded, give me a week's notice that we're going to lose you, ha, ha. How are you, Steiner?
I can't complain.  Brandt stands up, shakes hands heartily, toward chair.
Make yourself comfortable. (extends cigarette case to Steiner) How was it in the hospital?
(laconically) Pretty good.
And the Rest Home?
I recommend it.
(laughs, then, casually) then gestures  That night you were wounded -- did you know that Captain Stransky led the Second Company's counter- attack?
That's what they tell me.
Is it true?
The counterattack was led by Lieutenant Meyer. Captain Stransky was nowhere in sight. Brandt and Kiesel exchange glances.
Are you sure of that?
Absolutely. In the first place, I would have seen him, and in the second place, Lieutenant Meyer had to report to the Captain what had been happening in the lines.
How do you know that?
I was there when Lieutenant Meyer phoned.
A-ha! (sharply, to Kiesel) Fetch Triebig. Kiesel GOES OUT.
(grimly) I think you're entitled to a little fun.
as it opens and Triebig and Kiesel COME IN. Triebig looks very worried. For a moment, Brandt just looks at Triebig who bites his lip. Finally, Brandt speaks. His voice is unusually soft and low.
You signed your Captain's report, Lieutenant Triebig. Were you present when Captain Stransky led the counterattack?
(after a notice- able hesitation)  I accompanied the commander to the hill and saw him calling several men around him. Then he sent me back to the command post.
Then how do you know that Stransky really led the counterattack? You signed a statement to that effect, Lieutenant Triebig.
I -- I learned of it from wounded men who were returning.
Can you give me the name of one of these wounded men?
They weren't staff men -- just company men. I -- I knew them only by sight. Besides, it was pitch dark when I spoke to them.

(icily) I want you to know, Lieutenant Triebig, that I have had your statements checked. Captain Kiesel will inform you of the results of our investigation. Steiner watches closely as Kiesel takes a sheet of paper out of his pocket, studies its contents for a moment.

(placidly) Our investigation so far has  disclosed that at the moment there are forty-two men in 2nd Company who took part in that counterattack. They declare Unanimously that the attack was led by Lieutenant Meyer. None of them saw Captain Stransky, and none of them heard that he was even with the company. Brandt turns to Triebig, who looks ds if he were standing against a wall watching an execution squad line up in fro of him.

To my mind, there is nothing more contemptible than snatching the laurels that properly belong to  a man who died in action. I shall abide by Sergeant Steiner's testimony. If he stands by his statement that Captain Stransky was not with the company, I shall be compelled to institute disciplinary proceedings against the Captain. You may go now. You are no longer needed here.
Yes, sir. He doesn't look at Steiner as he LEAVES the room.
(to Steiner) Very well. Do you stand by your  statement? To Brandt's surprise, Steiner doesn't answer immediately. Then, after some hesitation:
Would it be possible for me to think it over for a few days?
(anger and disappoint- ment in his voice) Think it over? What is there to think over? Did you see Stransky or not? Steiner doesn't answer.
I don't understand you. Are you a friend of Stransky's? My im-  pression is that you wish him in hell.
My differences with Captain Stransky are a private matter.
(losing patience) Oh, they are? Why were you ordered to dig Stransky's bunker tonight? Steiner compresses his lips.
I asked you something! Steiner looks up, their eyes meet.
Do you want to hear lies?
(leaning forward) Do you know that Stransky intends to recommend disciplining you?
(a growl) If I were he, I wouldn't lose a minute about it.
(to Kiesel) I really think I should place a guard over him and have him dig holes until he's blue in the face.
(shrugs)  Why try to revise the decisions of Providence?
(sternly, to Steiner) Listen to me. You know I've always shown a great deal of understanding for you. But I am beginning to get tired of battling with your superiors over you.

(defiantly) I didn't ask you to. AS soon as the words are out, it is obvious from Steiner' expression that he regrets going that far, but it is too late. Brandt rises and leans on his desk. His voice is hoarse with rage.
Didn't ask me to! You didn't ask me to! Have you gone clean out of your mind? Do you have any idea what you're saying?
Steiner -- you ungrateful idiot -- For a second, Steiner closes his eyes. Se is struggling not to let the words out -- but they come pouring forth violently.

What are you asking me, Captain Kiesel? To love Colonel Brandt? I hate Colonel Brandt. I hate you, Captain Kiesel, and Stransky and Triebig, and ever since I've  put on this damn uniform I've hated everybody and anybody connected with it. If I get into any trouble, if I have any problem with anything or anybody, I'll solve them myself --! Thank you very much! Me pauses, shaking. There is a dead silence in the room. Brandt is breathing heavily. His unsteady hands grope across the top of his desk.
(his voice broken) Get out. Get out of here at once! Steiner doesn't move for a split second, then he GOES OUT Brandt tries to regain control of himself. Kiesel looks at the floor.

head_text.subj: LINE OF TRUCKS AND MARCHING MEN

text: all headed west. This is followed by QUICK CUTS of the troop-laden trucks. The total impression is of a gigantic exodus.

Steiner, Schnurrbart, Kruger, Zoll, and Anselm are all present. They have packed all their belongings, ready to move out. Schnurrbart and Kruger are playing cards. Steiner is sitting quietly on his bunk. The others are moving about -- obviously beset by impatience. Why the hell aren't we moving out?
What's everybody so worried about? Moving a regiment is quite a job, let me tell you. It doesn't move all at once. The PHONE RINGS.
Ah -- that's probably our orders now. AS Steiner goes to the phone, everybody makes for their packs, ready to leave at the word.
(into phone) Yes -- yes, sir -- I see -- (no change of expression)  Yes, sir -- at what time? -- Yes, sir.
(to Steiner, who has hung up) What's the good word?
The good word is that we've been elected. (cautiously) Elected to -- what?
Captain Stransky's paid us a great honor. We -- that is, our platoon -- is to stay here as a rear guard  until dark. For two hours. Maybe three. The men are frozen in disbelief.
I think we ought to feel very proud.
Those idiots are crazy.
Not so crazy. They're pulling out, we're not.
(takes a map from his pocket, spreads it on the table, traces with his thumb)  The division is moving back to new positions east of Krimskaya --
(nodding) Much easier to launch an offensive from there.
Why us? Of all the platoons in the battalion, why us? (violently) Because our sergeant is such a pal of Captain Stransky'e! That's why us!
I'm sorry. In the next war I'll try  to pick my enemies more carefully.

The car stands outside Stransky's bunker. A military CHAUFFEUR is at the wheel, and the MOTOR is RUNNING. A steady stream of trucks and equipment, headed west, flows past the staff car. In the b.g. the door to Stransk bunker flies open and the Captain with Lieutenant Triebig behind him, STEPS OUT. As they make for the car, the phon within the bunker is HEARD RINGING.
as Stransky comes INTO the SCENE, picks up phone. Triebig is in the b.g.

Captain Stransky -- Yes, yes, Captain Kiesel, we were just about to leave -- Yes, sir --  What's that, sir? (his expression is cloudy as he listens) I see, sir. Yes, sir. I'll attend to that immediately. Yes, sir. He hangs up. Triebig looks at him inquiringly.

Intelligence reports that the Russians are already on the high- way. Regiment feels that it would be not only useless but suicidal to leave behind any rear guard platoons. They're to join the evacuation immediately.
I see.  He and Stransky exchange glances.
Shall I call -- I believe it's Sergeant Steiner's platoon, is it not? Stransky nods. Triebig waits for him to say something, but he doesn't so Triebig picks up the phone.
Just a second, Lieutenant -- Triebig turns to face Stransky.

What do you think of this story? We tried to establish telephone communication with Steiner's bunker, but evidently his wires had already been cut. You, Lieuten-  ant Triebig, upon personal investigation, discovered their bunker abandoned. Apparently, the platoon had already left to take up its forward position. The two men look at each other. Then!
(slowly) I think it's an excellent story.
Just a story?
Much more than a story. I think it's fully justified.
You do? Why?

(after a moment's thought) It is my firm conviction that the Third Reich would be better off without the likes of Steiner and his cronies. The two men stand looking at each other without speaking. Then Stransky takes the telephone wire in his two hands and yanks it out of the wall. He doesn't look at Triebig as he strides from the bunker. Triebig follows.
All the men, with the exception of Steiner, are present. They are busy packing ammunition boxes.
Damn it. I hate to leave this place. We worked weeks fixing this place up -- this damn army.
The trouble with you is -- you're scared stiff.
(looks at him) You don't know how grateful we are that you were sent to us. It's nice to have one brave man in the platoon.
as it opens, and Steiner, his uniform wringing wet, COMES IN.
Well -- are we all still here? What do you mean "still here"?
(pretending surprise) No deserters? (walking to table) All right, then, let's have a look at the map before we start. He looks at map. The men gather around him. How far is it to Krimskaya?
About twenty miles. (staring thought- fully at the map)  The stuff between is regular wilderness. And a stream running through. (MORE)
How big a stream? Suppose there's no bridge? And the whole region is marshy. The big question is whether we can get through.
Then let's use the highway. Steiner just looks at him. (anxiously) What does that look mean? Did you see any Russians on the high-  way?
Infantry, trucks, tanks, the whole damn Russian army. There is a moment's silence. On the highway?
Not in the air, take my word for it.
(strapping on ammuni- tion box) How are we going to cross the highway with the Russians on it?
It's dark, it's raining--and there are bound to be a few gaps in the procession. We'll wait for the right moment and scoot across. It's hopeless. It's just plain suicide.
(slinging his tommy gun over his shoulder) We're eight self-reliant, resource- ful Germans. We'll make it.

(sardonically to Kern) There! Do you feel better?  Suppose we do make it. The Russians will be in Krimskaya before us. That means to get to our lines, we'll have to cross theirs. How? How, I'm asking?
(his boxes are strapped to him) We can tunnel beneath the Russians -- or we can pole vault over them. Are we all ready? (groaning) You can joke, but we're finished. Finished.

Of course we are. No doubt about it. And because you have so brilliantly pointed that out, you may lead the way. He flings the door open I motions for Kern to start the exodus. Kern looks sour, but leads the way. The others squeeze past Steiner at the door. When they are GONE, Steiner kicks the stove so that it falls over, spilling its golden embers on the floor. Then he GOES OUT, closing the door behind him.

huddled together in the rain, waiting for Steiner. After a moment, he comes INTO the SCENE. He jerks his head in the direction he wishes them to take. Then he starts off. The men exchange glances, but no one says a word. They trudge off.
It is still dark, but in the east the sky is beginning to lighten. In the distance WE SEE the line of men walking slowly, their heads bent against the rain.

The ANGLE FAVORS Zoll and Kern. They are panting under th burden of their machine-guns and boxes of ammunition. They are cursing under their breaths. The CAMERA PANS DOWN to their boots. They are caked with great lumps of muddy soil.
His face expressionless, he is walking steadily on. Ahead of him the terrain begins to slope upward. Suddenly, Steiner stops in his tracks r holds his hands up for the men to stop.

What the devil's the matter now? No one answers. Schnurrbart motions for them to listen. After a moment, the low DRONE of big MOTORS, the CREAKING of heavily laden TRUCKS is HEARD. Also an occasional windblown SHOUT is HEARD.

(whispering) Russians. (nervously) A whole army. With quivering fingers he unthinkingly reaches for his cigarettes and thrusts one between his lips. As he strike a match, Steiner suddenly APPEARS in front of him. There  is a sharp SLAPPING SOUND, followed by a RAIN of SPARKS from the crushed cigarette. Kern utters a whimpering sound and presses both hands against his mouth.
(voice thick with rage) You idiot! The men look at him in alarm, but he whirls around and runs forward, signaling for the men to follow.

as he walks along. There is a burn on his upper lip which he pats tenderly. His face is clouded with resent- ment. The VOICES ahead become increasingly distinct. The crisp TREAD of nailed boots is very marked -- grows even louder.
signaling for the men to halt. He walks back to the group.

(to Schnurrbart and Anselm) You come with me. The rest will wait here. Steiner, Anselm and Schnurrbart run off. The men watch th as, bent low, they DISAPPEAR into the darkness. Then, one by one, the men sink down onto the wet ground. For a few moments no one has the strength or the inclination to speak. Then --
He shouldn't have hit you.
Why not?
What's more important than the treatment of one German soldier by another -- I'd like to know.
I'll tell you what's more important -- (MORE)
(brings his face close to Zoll's) It's more important that we have to get out of here. And you know why? I'll tell you -- He pokes his finger into Zoll's chest. back.

Zoll moves indignantly  We have to get out so that we'll be on time to get into the next mess. Out of one mess into the next. That's been going on for three years, and it'll go on until we get into one mess good and deep and don't come out of it -- He has worked himself into such a rage that he can't go o There is another morose silence. Zoll sits up on one elbow, listens.

I think all that activity on the highway is slackening. Don't worry. We'll never get across.  He stops, for everyone is listening intently. He listens too. There isn't a sound from the direction of the highwa (whispering) I don't hear a thing....
Here comes somebody -- Every head turns.

head_text.subj: A FIGURE COMING OUT OF THE MIST

text: From the group's P.O.V. The figure stops.
It's Anselm. Anselm stops, waves his fist in the air.
Let's go.  They snatch their guns, run up the slope, DISAPPEAR into the mist.

Beneath it lies the highway in the gray dawn LIGHT. Deserted. In the b.g. WE SEE the platoon slipping down the steep decline and racing across the trampled, rutted width of the road toward the edge of the woods which rise like a dark wall against the further mountains.

He is standing about 100 yards in the forest, looking tow the highway. The men can be seen running towards him. In a few seconds, they reach Steiner. As they fight to catch their breaths, Steiner looks at them, triumph in hi eyes. Well --  Steiner holds up his hand for quiet. rumble of vehicles can be HEARD from the highway.
(grinning) Now that we're here that sounds like music to me.
(dryly) I think it's a little early for congratulations. (picks up his gear) We're ready.
Sergeant -- Steiner turns to regard him.
They listen. The  Before we start, there's a matter I'd like to bring up. The matter of your treatment of a comrade, Private Kern. Steiner looks at him closely.
One soldier of the Fuhrer is just as -- good as -- He wilts under Steiner's gaze, stops.
(coldly) Please continue. Just as good as what?

(weakening) Anyway -- I believe I speak for  all the others -- Steiner looks at the others. (to Zoll) Why don't you mind your own lousy business! It was idiotic of me to light that cigarette. Now, let's go. Steiner looks at Zoll, then, without a word, turns and starts walking. The others follow.

The scene is one of great bustle and activity. Trucks are unloading. Anti-aircraft guns are being set up on empty lots between houses. A Staff car speeds INTO the SCENE, jolts to a stop before one of the houses. Captain Kiesel  alights, taking a salute from the SENTRY, ENTERS one of the houses.
are supervising the installation of phones. Kiesel comes RUNNING IN.
You're slow with those phones, Captain. Regiment has been trying to speak to you.
They'll be in any minute, Captain Kiesel.
with the Russians breathing down our necks, the Colonel wants a patrol out front. I think Steiner's  the most experienced --
Sorry, Captain. I haven't the faintest idea of the whereabouts of Steiner and his platoon.
What do you mean by that? (stares at Stransky) You mean you didn't pull him out of line and bring him back? You had your orders.
I tried to contact Steiner immediately -- wasn't that so, Lieutenant?
Yes, Captain.
But he had already moved his platoon from the bunker.
Why? He had orders not to move till dark.
(shrugging) You know Steiner Disobeying orders is a speciality of his.
How the devil is he going to get back here? He's got the whole Russian army to get through.
He had his orders--he disregarded  them.

It doesn't sound like Steiner. He'd risk his own neck, not a whole platoon's -- (looks at Stransky closely) I think I can promise you a full investigation, Captain Stransky, when Steiner gets back. If he gets back. He turns and walks OUT rapidly. The telephone men are still in the room, so Stransky and Triebig can only excha covert congratulatory glances. The CAMERA MOVES to the window, THROUGH IT to an open field and as it MOVES EAST.

The CAMERA MOVES DOWN through thorny undergrowth until it picks up Steiner's platoon, fighting their weary way through. The undergrowth has ripped the men's uniforms and scratched their hands and faces. Sweat is pouring from their faces. They are almost continually s lapping a almost invisible stinging mites which hover about them. The CAMERA PANS DOWN to two pair of boots slogging throug the marsh. It is evident that they are suffering a great deal.

head_text.subj: THE SUN LOW IN THE SKY

text: It will be dark in a little while. From THIS ANGLE the CAMERA ZOOMS DOWN into the forest. It picks out Steiner trudging in water that is halfway up to his knees. There is no one in sight behind him. Suddenly, from the rear there are HOARSE SHOUTS. Steiner stops, turns,  listens. The SHOUTS are HEARD again. Steiner starts back, CAMERA TRUCKING with him. There is a slight rise in the terrain, which is firm and dry. are stretched out on the ground.
What's the trouble?
You'll have to call a rest, Rolf.
(tersely) We're not even half way yet.
I know, but what can't be done can't be done.
(reluctantly) Most of the men  All right. He notices Zoll, who is lying on his stomach off to one side, his head pillowed in his arms.
Where are your ammunition boxes? The others become attentive. Zoll doesn't stir. Steiner digs the toe of his boot into Zoll's side.
Didn't you hear me?
(a grunt) Leave me alone.
He had them ten minutes ago. The swine must have dumped them.
Then he'll go back for them. Zoll still doesn't move, so Steiner grips him by his cartridge belt and pulls him to his feet. Face twisted with fury, Zoll whirls, snatches up his rifle, brandishes it.
(hoarsely) Keep your dirty paws off me. If you touch me again. Steiner looks into Zoll's rabid face with a sort of curiosity.

(quietly) You're too much of a coward. Watch! He drops his tommy gun and gestures Schnurrbart and Kruge  back. They watch worriedly as Steiner steps so close to Zoll that the barrel of his rifle touches his stomach. Quietly he reaches out, grasps the rifle by the barrel an takes it from Zoll's hands. A sort of relieved sigh goes up from the men. Zoll stands motionless, his face re- flecting fear, rage and shame. Steiner picks up his tommy gun.
Get those boxes. Zoll hesitates for just a second. Then he turns and walks off INTO the brush. The men look after him grimly.
making his way to the top. When he nears it, he pushes aside two branches to give himself a view.
An enormous expanse of reeds cuts a swath across the  woods. Brown water shimmers along the thick stems. Then there is a hundred yard width of muddy water, then more weeds.
He looks grim as he starts his descent.
as they wait for Steiner. I bet this is the only dry spot for miles around. Why don't we just stay here?
Don't be silly. They won't know where to send our pay. Ah -- For Steiner has dropped out of the tree.
Well -- ?
Reeds, swamp, open water, more reeds, more swamp. Worse than I thought it would be. Steiner spreads the map on the ground. The men look over his shoulders. Steiner points to something on the map.
(nods) Tomorrow morning we'll start before dawn.
(querulously) Straight into the creek?
Shut up! We'll march north to the road. How far is that?
About thirty miles.
Thirty miles! It's crazy! This way we're no more than eight miles from Krimskaya!
Sure. If we could cross that swamp, and we can't!
Before I march thirty miles I need something to eat.
If you've got to have something to eat, try tree bark. Boiled in soft water it's supposed to be edible. Damn it all, don't act like a bunch of children. They look shame-faced, but Kruger growls...
You've seen what the water looks like. Like a hundred cows have been scheissing in it.
Then boil it and skim it. You won't mind the filth -- you've got a pig's stomach anyway. The men grin.

We'll make a soup. Put the meat and bread right in it. Kruger and Schnurrbart fetch water. But don't anybody try drinking the muck before it's boiled. The rest of us can gather wood. The men make a movement to start.
Wait a minute -- we may as well settle this now. We'll need a volunteer for sentry duty tonight. At least to start it off -- Nobody answers. The men don't look at each other.

I know you're all tired, but --  Sergeant, I -- At this moment, a NOISE in the brush causes all heads to turn. An exhausted Zoll, lugging the ammunition boxes' struggles INTO the SCENE. Steiner looks at him, then turn to Kern.
That's all right. The problem is solved. The men laugh, start off. Zoll looks puzzled by the laugh

The CAMERA PULLS BACK to REVEAL Kruger, Schnurrbart, Kern and Anselm asleep on the ground in various uncomfortable postures. Pawn is breaking in the sky. The air is filled with the croaking SOUND of FROGS.
as he slowly awakens. It is a moment before he is fully awake. He reaches out and nudges Kern awake. Huh? -- What? -- Oh -- what's up?
Where's Steiner, do you know? He just got up sometime ago and went off somewhere.
Did he say where? By this time the conversation has awakened the other men. I asked him, but you know Steiner -- he just gave me a look and off  he went. I got the shits.
(grimly) Steiner goes -- and you get scared' huh?
(looks around at all the faces) We're all scared the minute Rolf's not around to hold our hands.
(tosses a branch into the fire, sending up a shower of sparks) He'll be back. Anselm, relieve Zoll.
(rebelliously) Why me?
Hurry up and relieve Zoll. On the double.

You and Schnurrbart -- big shots! Lousy noncoms! You're all alike. Rank goes right to your heads. It stinks. The whole damned army stinks. And you, Kruger, stink worst of all! Kruger picks up a dry stick of wood which is only partial in the fire and tosses it at Anselm, who barely throws hi hand up in time. Then, with a cry of rage, he jumps acros the firs and onto Kruger's neck. The two men struggle on  the ground.
(simultaneously) Come on, now - stop it. Kruger! Anselm! Zoll comes running IN from his sentry post.

What's going on here? Zoll, assisted by Kern, tries to separate the two men who are locked together on the ground. Watch out -- somebody's going to get burned in the fire! Suddenly, Steiner's voice is heard.
Zoll -- Kern! Let them fight it out.
His gun is in the back of an elderly RUSSIAN. The others are in the b.g.
Why shouldn't they kill each other? Why should the Russians have to do it?
Who the hell is that? The old man sinks to the ground.
It's my guess he's a very old Russian -- what's yours?
Where did you find him, Rolf?
There's a dirt road about four miles from here. The road leads to a bridge. He was guarding it.
A bridge! A bridge that crosses the swamp, you mean?
Eureka, that means we don't have to march thirty miles to the highway, doesn't it?
Not to mention the forty more to Krimskaya.
(feeling his throat)  Doesn't anybody care that my neck is broken?
Not so fast. On the other side of the bridge there's a house. and there are Russians in the house. Pause.
How do you know -- did you see any?
No, but there was smoke coming out of the chimney. You ask him how many there are. Kruger talks in Russian to the old man, who replies. Then
He says there's two wagons and  two horses.
To hell with that. Ask him how many men there are in that house. Kruger speaks in Russian, but the old man just shakes his head.
How many men are there in the house? Kruger speaks to the old man who closes his eyes and turn his head aside.
He won't say.

(putting the muzzle of his gun against  the old man's head He has to. Ask him again. Kruger expostulates with the Russian, illustrating his wo with unmistakable gestures. The Russian slowly opens his eyes. Steiner is regarding him without expression. A brief smile passes over the Russian's wrinkled, parchment like face, and he says a few words.
What is he saying?
He says he is an old man.
(calmly) We can see that. I admire him, but I'm going to have to shoot him.
Isn't it dangerous, firing a shot? There may be some of them around, looking for him.
You may be right. On the other hand, we can't waste time hanging him. Pause.
Well, let's see -- there's strangu- lation, drowning, stoning --
If we had the time we'd let you talk him to death. Pause. Steiner takes a knife from his scabbard. The men are very silent.
Any volunteers?
(after a moment) How about you, Zoll? You were a butcher in civilian life, weren't you? The joke falls flat, even with Anselm.
(after a moment) If everybody's scared, I might have a try at it.

No. I'll make it quick and clean. (lifts the Russian to his feet, to  Kruger) We'll give him one more chance. Tell him what I'm going to do. Kruger speaks to the Russian who says nothing, doesn't even shake his head.
All right, then -- He pushes the Russian ahead of him toward a grove of smal trees, CAMERA TRUCKING with them.
They stand around in silence. A low GASP is HEARD O.S. The men tense. Anselm ventures to look off.
Steiner is seen bent over, leaning against a tree.
I'll say this for Steiner. At least he's throwing up. All eyes are fixed o.s. After a few moments, Steiner comes back IN. His knife and scabbard are both gone.
All right, get your things together.
I wonder how many Russians there are in that house.
